content.title: This is not about me losing my iPod
content.desc: We all have things that burn us up from this inside that are very hard to talk about, but once we can open up more about our hardships it's easier to heal.
tags: this deserves like more than four panels to be real

content.desc: Four Panel comic about adopting my cat :3

content.title: Taking Care of Myself (when I'm SICK)
content.desc: In my comic class we would always have a 10 minute warm up comic based on a prompt we would do at the start of class- this particular week, we did class virtually cause our professor was sick and thus the prompt we responded to was what do we do while we are sick.

content.title: Imitation is the highest form of flattery ♡
content.desc: A one-panel comic where I tried to stuff as much story into a square as I could! I really liked the visual pun of this cockroach "copying" the habits of this person whose own appearance resembles the cockroach's exoskeleton. There is also a redundant amount of coffee, to exaggerate the mimicry.
tags: Imitation is the highest form of flattery ♡

content.title: Surroundings
content.desc: I made this zine, printed it bound it as a set of three prints, two of which I sent to my professor and a classmate. I wrote on the back that it is "A Zine about the way we are impacted/can impact our surroundings and environments through art and our experiences."

content.title: Oh Snap!
content.desc: This two-color Risogrpah print on paper documents the very short version of an incident my boyfriend and I encountered very early on in the pandemic, before we knew how long “spring break” of 2020 was going to be. This was part of the Sancutary Exhibition in the Fenwick Gallery: https://fenwickgallery.gmu.edu/exhibitions/sanctuary-zines/sanctuary-artists/raquel-bumgarner/

content.title: The Egg - Inktober 2021
content.desc: My Inktober project for my Comics class, in which we made 25 panels over the 31 days of October that were all related to each other. I chose to tell a loose story about a girl and her dragon. Ink on Paper.

content.title: Inktober 01 2022
content.desc: A witch loosely based on Winifred Sanderson in Hocus Pocus, which I was watching when I drew this.

content.title: Inktober 02 2022
content.desc: A cat sits on a garden wall overlooking a pond... Ballpoint pen on paper... This was the year I tried to do full 8 x 11 illustrations every day for inktober, and I burnt out fast! I applied that lesson to a more manageable work flow the following inktober 2023...

content.title: Inktober 2023
content.desc: My Inktober for 2023- I made these while I was travelling, and to keep drawing for each day of the month manageable I decided to delegate it to post-its in my sketchbook. I used two different prompt lists- Booapple and Adventuretober 2023

content.title: Flora
content.desc: Recolorized image found on the internet archive, masked over a photo I took in the woods by my parent's home.

content.title: CinemaCat
content.desc: A Cinemagraph I made from my New Media class; I used a video of my cat and pictures of wildlife I took around Northern Virginia and compiled them in Photoshop.

content.title: Summit Avenue Ensemble and the Record Portal
content.desc: I found a picture of these guys on the internet archive, recolored them, found some other images on Unsplash, and collaged them in photoshop over a picture I had taken of trains in Denver, Colorado.

content.title: Absence: light, muted, blue, and dark
content.desc: Four photomanips of my cat in her cat tree, differing only in the amount of contrast and color correction around the negative space of said cat.

content.title: Physics and Astronomy Mural
content.desc: A Mural depicting stylized planetary and electromagnetic designs, commissioned by the Physics and Astronomy Department.

content.title: School of Art and Design Mural
content.desc: This mural represents each of the different schools within the GMU College of Visual and Performing Arts. Dean Rick Davis commissioned this mural for a hallway in college hall, and requested the topographical features referencing the dean's 10th meridian project. What you see here is a mash up of several pictures I took as it is in a long narrow hallway. This took several months to complete with my fellow Mural Brigade members.

content.title: Liza's Mural
content.desc: The first mural I designed; it was for the School of Art Marketing and Communications Manager. The black speech bubble was done with chalk paint so she could write current events on it.

content.title: Defund the Police Mural Design
content.desc: This was the original design I made for Sunrise Movement Richmond- as you can see with the image on the right some details such as shading of the statue and the activist were not implemented in the finished mural. Names of Black Virginian victims of police violence (Olajuwon Murphy, Marcus-David Peters, Natasha McKenna, Nat Turner, Terry Smith, Frankie Pitt, and Taft Sellers) frame the central image of a young Black activist holding a camera standing on top of a fallen confederate statue.

content.title: Defund the Police
content.desc: This mural was commissioned by Sunrise Movement Richmond in 2020; it was painted by myself and volunteers from Sunrise Virginia with acrylic paints on a 30 x 50 foot blue tarp and hung off the side of the Lee Bridge in Richmond, VA on Juneteenth 2020. It is a reinterpretation of Virginia's state flag with a young activist toppling a paint-splotched confederate statue; names of Black Virginian victims of police violence (Olajuwon Murphy, Marcus-David Peters, Natasha McKenna, Nat Turner, Terry Smith, Frankie Pitt, and Taft Sellers) are written in red around the central image. Photo by Vijay Iyre.
